item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Shipping a Serious, but Overlooked, Source of China’s Pollution, Report Says
item.description: Container vessels use a cheap fuel that emits a dense trail of soot and helps cause the small-particle pollution that hangs over many Chinese cities, the Natural Resources Defense Council said.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY
item.media:description: An employee viewing the Port of Shanghai, the world's busiest, from an office window.

item.title: In Liberia, a Good or Very Bad Sign: Empty Beds
item.description: Liberia has far fewer people being treated for Ebola than anticipated, but health officials are hesitant to declare victory.
item.dc:creator: By SHERI FINK
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Ebola field hospital in Bong County, Liberia, which opened in mid-September, has far fewer patients than anticipated.

item.title: Mexican Held in Shootings Was Deported After Arrests
item.description: The case could create a new problem for the Obama administration, as officials weigh steps the president could take after the Nov. 4 elections to expand protections from deportation for immigrants here illegally.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER MEDINA and JULIA PRESTON
item.media:credit: Randall Benton/The Sacramento Bee, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Two sheriff’s officers were killed Friday in a shooting in California.

item.title: Computing the Political Impact of Canada’s Attacks
item.description: After two attacks by homegrown extremists, the questions now are about the impact on Prime Minister Stephen Harper’s future.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL WINES and IAN AUSTEN
item.media:description: Prime Minister Stephen Harper, center, after the funeral for Cpl. Nathan Cirillo on Tuesday.

item.title: Frustration in Search for 43 Students in Mexico
item.description: Led to a dump near Cocula, the authorities seemed no closer to finding the students who vanished after being arrested a month ago in Iguala.
item.dc:creator: By PAULINA VILLEGAS and ELISABETH MALKIN
item.media:description: Soldiers escorted a convoy carrying forensics experts to a mountainous area in the state of Guerrero.

item.title: North Korean Diplomats Extend Offer for Visit, U.N. Official Says
item.description: The reported gesture came amid intrigue over the North’s leader, Kim Jong-un, who South Korean intelligence officials said was recovering from surgery on his left foot.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Korea News Service, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The North Korean leader Kim Jong-un in Pyongyang, in an undated image released by the Korean Central News Agency.

item.title: Open Source: Echoes of Patty Hearst in Kobani
item.description: Narration by the British hostage John Cantlie on Islamic State propaganda videos is reminiscent of recordings by the kidnapped Patty Hearst.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A screen shot from video recorded recently in Kobani, Syria, by Islamic State militants shows a distinctive silver silo topped by a Turkish flag near the border between Turkey and Syria.

item.title: Egypt Orders Evacuation Along Gaza Border to Thwart Militants
item.description: Egyptian officials plan a buffer zone next to the Hamas-ruled territory, only days after an army post was attacked.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Ecuador: Tortoise Species Is Saved
item.description: Conservationists said Tuesday that they had brought giant tortoises on the Galápagos island of Española back from the brink of extinction.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Arequipa Journal: Despite Rumors, Not Everything That Towers Is Eiffel’s
item.description: In parts of Peru and Chile, famed engineer Gustave Eiffel’s name is linked to many structures he had nothing to do with.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Iron Bridge in Arequipa, Peru.

item.title: World Briefing: Brazil: Deadly School Bus Crash
item.description: Eleven people, mostly teenagers, were killed when a truck loaded with vegetable oil collided head-on with a bus full of high school students in southeastern Brazil, near Ibitinga, the police said Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Turkey: Flooding Traps Miners
item.description: Underground water flooded a section of a coal mine in southern Turkey on Tuesday, trapping at least 18 workers, officials and reports said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Britain: Setback for Public Nudity
item.description: A British man nicknamed the Naked Rambler has lost a legal bid to have public nudity declared a human right.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Burkina Faso: Marchers Push Leader Not to Seek Another Term
item.description: The police fired tear gas at rock-throwing protesters after tens of thousands marched through the capital calling for President Blaise Compaoré to scrap plans to change term limits to stay in power.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: President of Italy Questioned in Mafia Case
item.description: President Giorgio Napolitano answered questions in a trial in which the state is accused of negotiating with Sicily’s Cosa Nostra to quell violence in the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: By GAIA PIANIGIANI

item.title: Iraqi Kurds Are Joining Fight to Drive Islamic State From Kobani
item.description: About 150 pesh merga fighters were expected to arrive as early as Tuesday night, taking advantage of Turkey’s decision to open its borders.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KAMIL KAKOL and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Conservative Group Urges Changes at Japanese War Shrine
item.description: A chapter of Izokukai, an influential association of families of the war bereaved, backed a proposal to separate war criminals from other war dead at the Japanese shrine.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: Russia Backs Plan by Ukraine Separatists for an Early Election
item.description: The Kremlin’s move set the stage for renewed tensions with the West because the vote is in violation of an agreement signed last month.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN and ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Lens Blog: A Festival of Ideas and Photos in Africa
item.description: The Lagos Photo Festival strives to foster encounters among photographers inspired by Africa and to nurture local artists.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID GONZALEZ
item.media:description: Afose Sulayman Senayon found that workshops encouraged him to document his community.

item.title: Letter From the Middle East: For Israelis and Palestinians, Another Divide to Contend With: Time
item.description: After decades of fighting over borders and refugees, Israelis and Palestinians cannot even agree on what time it is, as their daylight saving calendars remain out of sync.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: As Oil Prices Fall, Iran Feels Pressure to Seal Nuclear Deal
item.description: President Hassan Rouhani has pledged a bright economic future to follow the lifting of sanctions, but his promises are starting to ring hollow as talks stall.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Mehdi Ghasemi for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mall in Tehran where business has been slow. Iranians hope a nuclear deal will end the sanctions that have hobbled the Iranian economy.

item.title: Online Security Experts Link More Breaches to Russian Government
item.description: Researchers say hackers have for seven years been using sophisticated techniques to break into computer networks around the world.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLE PERLROTH
item.media:description: An Independence Day ceremony in Georgia, which is said to be the target of Russian hackers.

item.title: Some Hamas Government Workers in Gaza to Get Salaries
item.description: Using a $30 million donation, the Palestinian Authority will distribute $1,200 each to about 24,000 public workers who have not been fully paid since last year.
item.dc:creator: By FARES AKRAM and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: French Culture Minister’s Prosaic Reading List Draws Criticism
item.description: An admission by the minister, Fleur Pellerin, that she has not read a book in two years, or any work by the Nobel winner Patrick Modiano, has set off a storm.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: Fleur Pellerin said that she reads “a lot of notes, a lot of legal texts, the news, A.F.P. stories,” but not books.

item.title: Hong Kong Lawmaker Pays Price for Breaking Ranks With Beijing
item.description: James Tien, the leader of the pro-Beijing Liberal Party, is set to be expelled from a prestigious Chinese government advisory panel, his brother said.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: James Tien, a pro-Beijing lawmaker, had called for Hong Kong’s leader to resign.
